question.title: Does scala affect AspectJ/Spring AOP at all? I'm having a thread locking problem when running tests when an @Configurable is being called

node.contents: Have you added the scala compiler to the build tag in the pom file?

astNode.text: Have you added the scala compiler to the build tag in the pom file?

node.contents: @abhin4v: I could, but it wouldn't matter because there are no scala class files to compiler. They are already compiled from other projects. I have tried this "for the heck of it", and it did nothing :(

astNode.text: @abhin4v: I could, but it wouldn't matter because there are no scala class files to compiler. They are already compiled from other projects. I have tried this "for the heck of it", and it did nothing :(

node.contents: So let me get this straight, there are no scala files, scala compiler is not added in the build config, only scala libs are added as dependency. And this error does not occur when you remove the scala dependencies. Right?

astNode.text: So let me get this straight, there are no scala files, scala compiler is not added in the build config, only scala libs are added as dependency. And this error does not occur when you remove the scala dependencies. Right?

node.contents: @abhin4v: I'm assuming it would, but it's now i'm possible to get rid of the scala dependencies to be 100% sure, because I spent an entire day coding functionality that now depends on them. I can't just disable the project's dependency and have it compile now :( I guess I could break a bunch of tests to be sure. I may as well do that.

astNode.text: @abhin4v: I'm assuming it would, but it's now i'm possible to get rid of the scala dependencies to be 100% sure, because I spent an entire day coding functionality that now depends on them. I can't just disable the project's dependency and have it compile now :( I guess I could break a bunch of tests to be sure. I may as well do that.

node.contents: @abhin4v: Yeah, actually I did "hg update -r xx" to go back and all the tests run fine before the scala additions.

astNode.text: @abhin4v: Yeah, actually I did "hg update -r xx" to go back and all the tests run fine before the scala additions.

node.contents: Okay, I verified it - scala's the problem. I remove scala from the test class path and the compile class path, and everything works again. ARGH!@!@!

astNode.text: Okay, I verified it - scala's the problem. I remove scala from the test class path and the compile class path, and everything works again. ARGH!@!@!

node.contents: Code, give us code.

astNode.text: Code, give us code.

node.contents: okay, i added a pile more code

astNode.text: okay, i added a pile more code

node.contents: I have a strange problem where when I run my tests using maven, it locks whenever a test method calls into an object with an annotation @Configurable. I can run the tests fine in IDEA using the AspectJ Weaver plugin (remarkably), but I cannot do it with maven (whether I execute them in IDEA or just in a terminal).

astNode.text: I have a strange problem where when I run my tests using maven, it locks whenever a test method calls into an object with an annotation @Configurable. I can run the tests fine in IDEA using the AspectJ Weaver plugin (remarkably), but I cannot do it with maven (whether I execute them in IDEA or just in a terminal).

node.contents: Even weirder, if I press ctrl-c, it does not kill the process. It just keeps a 500meg process in memory for eternity until I kill it using the System Monitor in Ubuntu.

astNode.text: Even weirder, if I press ctrl-c, it does not kill the process. It just keeps a 500meg process in memory for eternity until I kill it using the System Monitor in Ubuntu.

node.contents: This problem never happened until I added Scala to my Java project. Note, I'm not compiling Scala code - just including jars that were compiled with scala and I'm including the Scala compiler/library jars as part of the classpath.

astNode.text: This problem never happened until I added Scala to my Java project. Note, I'm not compiling Scala code - just including jars that were compiled with scala and I'm including the Scala compiler/library jars as part of the classpath.

node.contents: Basically, Maven will run a bunch of tests and then hang:

astNode.text: Basically, Maven will run a bunch of tests and then hang:

Running jobprep.domain.question.openended.OpenEndedStudentSubmissionDeserializerTests

node.contents: When it comes to OpenEndedStudentSubmissionDeserializerTests, it freezes. It would appear that the reason why is that OpenEndedStudentSubmissionDeserializer is using @Configurable. If I comment out the test class and run the tests again, it'll just freeze on the next test class that uses @Configurable.

astNode.text: When it comes to OpenEndedStudentSubmissionDeserializerTests, it freezes. It would appear that the reason why is that OpenEndedStudentSubmissionDeserializer is using @Configurable. If I comment out the test class and run the tests again, it'll just freeze on the next test class that uses @Configurable.

node.contents: EDIT: It's interesting enough, if I tell maven to just run the tests in the "jobprep.domain.question.openended" package, it works 100%. If I tell it to run everything in "jobprep.domain", it still works! If I tell it to run everything in "jobprep", then the problem happens.

astNode.text: EDIT: It's interesting enough, if I tell maven to just run the tests in the "jobprep.domain.question.openended" package, it works 100%. If I tell it to run everything in "jobprep.domain", it still works! If I tell it to run everything in "jobprep", then the problem happens.

node.contents: Is there something I should be aware of with Scala, AspectJ, Spring, etc. when it comes to this root package?

astNode.text: Is there something I should be aware of with Scala, AspectJ, Spring, etc. when it comes to this root package?

node.contents: In Maven, if I tell surefire to load only a subset of my tests, it works. 893 out of the 1096 tests in my test suite will run and pass. This isn't perfect though because I need to get the remaining tests to work still:

astNode.text: In Maven, if I tell surefire to load only a subset of my tests, it works. 893 out of the 1096 tests in my test suite will run and pass. This isn't perfect though because I need to get the remaining tests to work still:

node.contents: It sucks that I have to be this fine-grained, but I don't know any other way to go about solving this problem.

astNode.text: It sucks that I have to be this fine-grained, but I don't know any other way to go about solving this problem.

node.contents: You know what's curious though? If I run the tests for controllers only, it works! Bloody hell! Could this mean they both run separately, but not together?!?

astNode.text: You know what's curious though? If I run the tests for controllers only, it works! Bloody hell! Could this mean they both run separately, but not together?!?

node.contents: I am scared to build this project and deploy to the server even though all the tests work in the IDE... because if the Aspects/AOP is locking up in tests, it probably doesn't work if I were to build and package the project using maven.

node.contents: In that case, it is hard to see how using a Scala jar affects @Configurable. I guess the only way to really figure this out is for you to create a separate small project and see if you can reproduce it. If you can, please share and I will take a look.

node.contents: One quick thing to try: Use 1.2 version of AspectJ maven plugin. I have experienced issues with 1.3.

node.contents: Nope... all of the @Configurable stuff is pure Java. In fact, it used to work 100% before I decided to use Scala for a minor aspect of the project. This is not a new project, but an existing one.

node.contents: Does your @Configurable type extends a Scala class? If you can post sample code (or ideally a simple Maven project) that shows how your @Configurable classes and Scala classes interact, that will help resolve it.

astNode.text: Does your @Configurable type extends a Scala class? If you can post sample code (or ideally a simple Maven project) that shows how your @Configurable classes and Scala classes interact, that will help resolve it.

node.contents: My guess is YES, aspectj is interfering with scala classes. Note that Scala has many inner and outer classes, and aspectj is apparently not terribly bright about determining what the outer class is.

astNode.text: My guess is YES, aspectj is interfering with scala classes. Note that Scala has many inner and outer classes, and aspectj is apparently not terribly bright about determining what the outer class is.
